I was crossing Washington street at green and Washington. The first car went straight. The second car turned into me coming about 3 feet from hitting me, before turning the wheel to speed down green street. There were 2 other pedestrians in the cross walk at the same time just 3 feet behind me.

Cars often don't stop at the stop sign at Pitt & Gibbon intersection, specifically on Gibbon Street heading West to Washington Street to get to 495. Cars have been totaled, pedestrians have been hit by cars and multiple times a day residents have seen cars drive through the stop sign. APD has assisted with accidents here and have watched the intersection but don't have resources to have a police car there all of the time. The intersection is right next to Lyle's Crouch and young children often cross the street. It's a main route for cars to leave the waterfront to get into 495 and it's become dangerous for primarily pedestrians and other cars crossing Gibbon Street. We've reached out to the City to address the issue and we applied for speed humps but the block is under the required length so the problem is still unresolved.

Cars driving West bound on Gibbon Street often drive through the stop sign at Pitt & Gibbon as they are exiting OldTown to access 495. This is a repeated issued and is dangerous for pedestrians  and cars crossing on Pitt street. Residents have been hit by cars and cars have been totaled at this intersection. 

This is a safety issue for children as it's an intersection next to Lyles Crouch. 

We have personally had several instances walking with our baby where cars do not stop at the stop sign. Residents have witnessed this happening multiple times a day. 

APD has been involved in the accidents that have taken place as well as coordinating with residents to try and watch the intersection but they don't have enough resources to monitor the intersection all of the time. 

We have applied for speed humps but the City rejected the request based on the length of the block. The issue still remains where it's an unsafe intersection for pediatricians and especially children.

Intersection of Prince and Columbus.

I was in the southbound lane of Columbus waiting at the intersection with Prince for the red light to change. Vehicle traveling southbound came dangerously close to hitting me, then the driver rolled down the window and started yelling at me to "get out of the street"

St. Asaph to pick up a passenger. I have some photos
column21: I live on this block and multiple times per week see cars turn the wrong way (west) on prince street b/c they do not realize that at this intersection, Prince street becomes one way. It is a head on collision waiting to happen. On this date, a car started to realize that as she was turning so instead swerved and drove on to the sidewalk, across the sidewalk and through a metal and iron fence, taking the fence down and almost hitting pedestrians. Since they removed the statue at the intersection of Prince & Washinton, the intersection at Prince and St Asaph has become more dangerous as cars are flying down that block of prince st at high rates of speed. That combined with many drivers turning the wrong way on Prince st as it just becomes one way there is a tragedy waiting to happen. This accident could have been deadly as there is a school located in the church right there and the students use this block as their carpool location as well as recess.

Noting there is no shoulder on the downhill side of the street, Running in the street is dangerous.  The boys ran up the hill on the sidewalk, but two of the boys rested by standing in the street, wearing all dark clothing, making it very hard to see them.  I didn’t notice one boy until I was nearly upon him.  It’s great that they are exercising on the hill but they should stay safely on the sidewalk.

column10: After waiting for the light to change to walk south across Duke Street from the northwest corner of Duke and Alfred, a vehicle that had also been waiting for the light to change to turn right/east onto Duke Street sped through the intersection without regard for me, the pedestrian, and did not slow or change direction as I stepped backward and called out to alert her to my presence.

Running south on Royal, I came to the intersection with Gibbon and prepared to cross in front of a car that stopped for another car at the intersection. The driver's attention was entirely on the other car and they never looked at me. It's well lit and I was wearing hi Viz clothing so they would have seen me if they did. I was wary so crossed cautiously and in a wide arc around the front of their car, and it saved me. They floored it right as I got in front of their hood and the extra few feet gave me just enough time to dive out of the way. Really shows the importance of making eye contact, being defensive, and drivers needing to not be mindless idiots.
column21: Marked "other" in driver behavior because the driver accelerated aggressively, which I have increasingly noticed. I get people are in a hurry but gunning it away from stop signs is really dangerous for pedestrians

column10: As I proceeded south on West St through the intersection with Jaimeson Ave, an SUV eastbound on Jaimeson proceeded through the stop sign and nearly hit me. The collision was only avoided through evasive action by me and sudden braking from the SUV.
column21:
This is unfortunately a common occurrence at this intersection. Southbound traffic on West St has no stop sign, whereas traffic eastbound on Jaimeson do. The vast majority of traffic southbound on West Ave turns westbound onto Jaimeson. Drivers at the stop sign thereby assume that all traffic will turn right and will proceed into the intersection despite other traffic on West. However, because there is a bike path bypassing the vehcile gate on West Ave, most bike traffic continues southbound. 

This is particularly challenging for bicyclists. If following a large vehicle southbound on West St, drivers at the stop sign have difficulty seeing around the large vehicle to the trailing bicyclist.

column10: Driver going south on Union St did not stop at Prince and almost hit a pedestrian
Rush Hour at Duke and South Columbus Street.  Lexus SVU heading south on S. Columbus turned left onto Duke ignoring pedestrian who was in crosswalk with the walk light.  Apparently in a hurry..
column21: This is a dangerous intersection all times.  Ideal location to install leading pedestrian indicator b/c every day including Sundays...drivers making left turns from all directions attempt to make left turn before oncoming traffic/peds/bikes.

column10: Silver BMW X2 with plate UDX 5918 turned right and almost ran over an elderly lady who was crossing King from the north along N West.
column21: A bollard at the corner or median traffic control device that forces drivers to make sharper turns would have protected the pedestrian by forcing the driver to turn safely.

column10: My wife and I were crossing with the leading walk signal and two cars made left turns together from Washington St onto west bound Gibbon before the traffic signal turned green for them. In other words, drivers use the leading pedestrian walk signal as their left turn signal to turn and get a jump on southbound Washington traffic.

Driver tried to pass in the far right lane headed south (which was empty because most cars know this lane turns into parking in the next block south) and blew through the red light for the intersection. They probably did not recognize the intersection because of all the stopped cars in the crosswalk. I was about to enter the crosswalk because I had the cross signal but hesitated because it didn’t look like the SUV was slowing down. I’m glad I ignored the walk signal and assumed the wrong driver action or I would’ve been hit at about 35+ mph
column21: This intersection is poorly designed at the expense of pedestrian and cyclist safety. There is no island or anything to force drivers to pay closer attention, and the crosswalk starts mid block at a building on the west side (3 way road)

column10: Driver of SUV going eastbound on Duke Street failed to stop while my family and I were in the crosswalk. Driver was holding a cell phone to their ear. We had pushed the walk signal at the crosswalk before crossing.

Southbound Driver marking left turn onto Queen Street did not stop for pedestrians in the crosswalk attempting to cross Queen street. Driver was driving fast and had an obstructed view to a large fire truck traveling east on Queen St that had just crossed the intersection

Driver of a black Audi SUV with MD plates attempted to overtake in oncoming lane, but ran out of room at the stop sign and ended up turning left onto West St from the westbound lane of Jamieson. There was a small child in the front seat of the SUV and I had my child with me on my bike during the incident. Aggressive driving is common on this part of Jamieson but bike infrastructure is too disconnected to be usable.
column21: Jamieson needs a protected bike lane from West Street to Mill road. It's a corridor for getting to Lyles Crouch elementary school and yet doesn't have safe paths on its length.

column10: Car rushed through the slip lane after the light turned, almost colliding with vehicles that were proceeding south on Henry towards the interstate.
column21: The slip lane is a consistent traffic danger at this intersection

column10: Driver turned left against oncoming traffic and after the pedestrian walkway changed. Nearly hit pedestrians crossing Holland towards the CVS.
column21: The left turn really conflicts with oncoming traffic and the pedestrian crossing at Holland Lane. The entire intersection is consistently poor with respect to pedestrians crossing between the CVS and Whole Foods stores.

column10: Blue Honda Accord with Virginia plates headed west on Wythe St. crossed the double yellow line and accelerated through the stop sign at N Patrick and Wythe in the oncoming lane of traffic. It seemed like they wanted to make the light a few blocks further - the city should install occlusion devices on those lights so that only cars directly in front of the light can see whether the light is green.

Someone driving an oversized pickup truck turned through the crosswalk as I was in the middle of it.  I was already well into the crosswalk when they stopped at the stop sign, so I definitely had right of way.  They nearly hit me - I had to jump out of the way - then gunned it around me as if it were my fault for daring to cross the street.  Trucks with large A frames are so dangerous

my wife and I were standing at the corner of Oronoco and N. St Asaph, waiting to walk east into a crosswalk after a driver of a car pass through the intersection driving south.  Once that driver passed through the 4-way stop sign intersection, I took one step into the crosswalk when we realized a driver of an SUV who was on Oronoco at the same side of the intersection as where we were standing, decided to make a right turn and came very close to crashing into us, even though as pedestrians who were starting to enter the crosswalk we had the right of way.  The driver must have seen us b/c we were right next to him at the corner.  He did not put on his right turning blinker but rather just went from a stopped position to making the right-hand turn.  I guess he assumed that he could beat us into the intersection.  He never slowed down but just drove as if we weren't there or had the right of way.

As I was walking through the crosswalk (at a normal pace, completely un-distracted), a driver which should have been at a complete stop was slowly inching toward me. As my right foot was almost on the curb, the driver took off and the bumper of the car grazed my heel. The driver was aware that their car made contact with a part of my body.

bus has stopped on Fairfax, going north, to pick up a rider at the corner of Fairfax and Princess.  I was at the corner of the crosswalk and waited for the bus to come to a full stop at the corner.  I started to enter the crosswalk when a driver of an SUV passed the bus and started to enter the intersection while I was a third of the way through the cross walk.  I stopped.  The driver slammed on his brakes but would have crashed into me if I had continued in the crosswalk.  Once he realized he wasn't going to hit me, he sped off through the intersection.
column21: driver passing a stopped bus didn't bother to slow down and look at a person crossing a crosswalk.
